name: Leather
description: Durable and flexible, commonly used for armor, boots, and belts. Often seen in rogue or ranger outfits.

name: Chainmail
description: Interlocking metal rings, providing good protection. Used in various types of armor, especially for knights and warriors.

name: Silk
description: Luxurious and lightweight, favored by mages and nobles for robes and cloaks.

name: Linen
description: Light and breathable, typically used for common wear, undergarments, or mage robes.

name: Wool
description: Heavy and warm, often used for cloaks, tunics, and pants, suitable for travel and colder climates.

name: Fur
description: Thick and insulating, used for warmth in cloaks, boots, and trims. Common in barbarian or northern character attire.

name: Brocade
description: Rich, decorative fabric with raised designs, often seen in noble or royal garments.

name: Velvet
description: Soft, with a distinctive feel, used for luxurious clothing and nobility's attire.

name: Scale
description: Small, overlapping plates, resembling fish scales. Used in armor for flexibility and protection.

name: Canvas
description: Sturdy and heavy-duty, used for durable clothing like pants and jackets, common for adventurers.

name: Damask
description: Woven fabric with patterns, seen in high-quality vests, robes, and gowns.

name: Suede
description: Soft and luxurious, used for gloves, boots, and caps, popular among rogues and bards.

name: Tweed
description: Durable and moisture-resistant, ideal for travel cloaks and scholar attire.

name: Mesh
description: Light and airy, used in layers for mystical or exotic outfits.

name: Gossamer
description: Sheer and lightweight, often used in elven attire or for magical robes.
